items.title: BAFTAs apologize after guest with Tourette syndrome uses racial slur during ceremony
items.standfirst: A man with Tourette syndrome shouted a racial slur and other offensive remarks during the BAFTA awards ceremony Sunday. The BBC did not edit out his outbursts in its delayed broadcast.
items.content: A man with Tourette syndrome shouted a racial slur and other offensive remarks during the BAFTA awards ceremony Sunday. The BBC did not edit out his outbursts in its delayed broadcast.(Image credit: Dominic Lipinski/Getty Images)

clusters.title: French minister moves to block US envoy Kushner from government access
clusters.neutral_headline: France bans US envoy after no show at meeting

items.title: French minister moves to block US envoy Kushner from government access
items.standfirst: The minister says Charles Kushner, father of Trump's son-in-law Jared, had failed to explain US comments about violence in France.
items.content: The minister says Charles Kushner, father of Trump's son-in-law Jared, had failed to explain US comments about violence in France.

items.title: France bans US envoy after no-show at meeting over killing of activist
items.standfirst: Charles Kushner had been summoned to explain comments relating to the killing of far-right activist Quentin DeranqueDonald Trump’s ambassador to Paris has been banned from meeting French government ministers after failing to show up for a meeting at the foreign ministry to explain US comments about the killing of a far-right activist.Charles Kushner, whose son Jared is married to the US president’s oldest daughter, Ivanka, was summoned to the 7pm meeting by the foreign minister, Jean-Noël Barrot, after the US embassy in Paris reposted state department comments about the case. Continue reading...
items.content: Charles Kushner had been summoned to explain comments relating to the killing of far-right activist Quentin DeranqueDonald Trump’s ambassador to Paris has been banned from meeting French government ministers after failing to show up for a meeting at the foreign ministry to explain US comments about the killing of a far-right activist.Charles Kushner, whose son Jared is married to the US president’s oldest daughter, Ivanka, was summoned to the 7pm meeting by the foreign minister, Jean-Noël Barrot, after the US embassy in Paris reposted state department comments about the case. Continue reading...

items.title: France curtails US Ambassador Kushner's government access after he fails to obey summons
items.standfirst: US Ambassador Charles Kushner "did not appear" after being formally summoned over comments the Trump administration made about the killing of a far-right activist in France, the foreign ministry said on Monday. Kushner will no longer have direct access to government ministers but will be allowed to perform certain diplomatic duties, the ministry said.
items.content: US Ambassador Charles Kushner "did not appear" after being formally summoned over comments the Trump administration made about the killing of a far-right activist in France, the foreign ministry said on Monday. Kushner will no longer have direct access to government ministers but will be allowed to perform certain diplomatic duties, the ministry said.

ai_summary: Charles Kushner failed to explain US comments about violence in France

Kushner was summoned to explain comments about a far-right activist
The US embassy in Paris reposted state department comments about the case
France curtails US Ambassador Kushner's government access

clusters.title: Greenland says 'no thanks' to Trump's hospital ship

items.title: Greenland says 'no thanks' to Trump's hospital ship
items.standfirst: Greenland's Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen said on ​Sunday "no thanks" to U.S. President Donald Trump's idea of sending a hospital ship to Greenland, a territory that Trump has ​repeatedly ‌said he wishes to take over. Trump said ⁠on Saturday on social media he was working with Louisiana Governor and ‌special envoy to Greenland, Jeff Landry, to send a ⁠hospital boat to Greenland.
items.content: Greenland's Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen said on ​Sunday "no thanks" to U.S. President Donald Trump's idea of sending a hospital ship to Greenland, a territory that Trump has ​repeatedly ‌said he wishes to take over. Trump said ⁠on Saturday on social media he was working with Louisiana Governor and ‌special envoy to Greenland, Jeff Landry, to send a ⁠hospital boat to Greenland.

clusters.title: Trump threatens ‘obnoxious’ tariffs as UK and EU seek clarity on trade deals
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump threatens obnoxious tariffs on UK and EU

items.title: Trump threatens ‘obnoxious’ tariffs as UK and EU seek clarity on trade deals
items.standfirst: US president suggests trade war could escalate as administration says it will stop collecting levies ruled illegal by supreme courtStock markets stumble as global trade faces more Trump tariff uncertaintyDonald Trump has declared that he can use tariffs in a “much more powerful and obnoxious way”, as the UK and the EU said they were seeking urgent clarity on the US trade deals they struck last summer.Trump threatened to escalate his global tariff war on Monday, after a supreme court ruling last week that he had overstepped his legal authority to impose his “liberation day” measures last year. Continue reading...
items.content: US president suggests trade war could escalate as administration says it will stop collecting levies ruled illegal by supreme courtStock markets stumble as global trade faces more Trump tariff uncertaintyDonald Trump has declared that he can use tariffs in a “much more powerful and obnoxious way”, as the UK and the EU said they were seeking urgent clarity on the US trade deals they struck last summer.Trump threatened to escalate his global tariff war on Monday, after a supreme court ruling last week that he had overstepped his legal authority to impose his “liberation day” measures last year. Continue reading...

items.title: Stock markets stumble as global trade faces more Trump tariff uncertainty
items.standfirst: US president’s international trade war spooks investors, with drops in US share prices after European lossesTrump threatens ‘obnoxious’ tariffs as UK and EU seek clarity on trade dealsStock markets stumbled on Monday as Donald Trump pushed ahead with fresh tariffs on the US’s trading partners despite a supreme court strike-down and growing opposition from domestic voters.Uncertainty over the status of global trade deals spooked investors, triggering a drop in US shares prices including on the Dow Jones industrial average, which tumbled 1.6% by Monday’s closing. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 fell 1.4% and 1.1%, after losses for European stock markets. Continue reading...
items.content: US president’s international trade war spooks investors, with drops in US share prices after European lossesTrump threatens ‘obnoxious’ tariffs as UK and EU seek clarity on trade dealsStock markets stumbled on Monday as Donald Trump pushed ahead with fresh tariffs on the US’s trading partners despite a supreme court strike-down and growing opposition from domestic voters.Uncertainty over the status of global trade deals spooked investors, triggering a drop in US shares prices including on the Dow Jones industrial average, which tumbled 1.6% by Monday’s closing. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 fell 1.4% and 1.1%, after losses for European stock markets. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Trump declares he can use tariffs in a more powerful way
The UK and EU seek clarity on US trade deals
Trump threatens to escalate his global tariff war
The supreme court ruled that Trump overstepped his authority
Stock markets stumble due to uncertainty over trade deals

items.title: How will FDA speed gene therapy approvals? #health
items.standfirst: New regulatory pathway aims to speed access for rare patients The Food and Drug Administration is moving to create a faster route for gene therapies meant to treat rare diseases, including bespoke treatments tailored to an individual patient’s mutation. Under the revised approach, regulators would…
items.content: New regulatory pathway aims to speed access for rare patients The Food and Drug Administration is moving to create a faster route for gene therapies meant to treat rare diseases, including bespoke treatments tailored to an individual patient’s mutation. Under the revised approach, regulators would…

items.title: The FDA creates a quicker path for gene therapies
items.standfirst: The Food and Drug Administration aims to evaluate treatments for rare diseases based on plausible evidence that they would work — without requiring a clinical trial first.
items.content: The Food and Drug Administration aims to evaluate treatments for rare diseases based on plausible evidence that they would work — without requiring a clinical trial first.(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

ai_summary: FDA aims to speed access for rare disease treatments

Treatments will be evaluated based on plausible evidence
